name: USACE
description: USACE provides engineering services to the Army, other military services, federal agencies, and state and local governments. It manages water resources, military construction, and environmental restoration.

budget.procurementBudget: $17.1 billion from Bipartisan Infrastructure Law through 2026

painPoints.point: Navigation infrastructure backlog - inland waterways locks and dams well beyond 50-year design life, $56.5M backlog for Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway alone
painPoints.source: ASCE Inland Waterways Infrastructure Report 2021 & Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway Association FY2025 Priorities

painPoints.point: PFAS contamination at 586 DOD military sites requiring remediation after EPA designated PFOA and PFOS as hazardous substances
painPoints.source: GAO-25-107401 Persistent Chemicals Report & EPA PFAS Actions 2024

painPoints.point: Deferred maintenance tracking gaps - GAO 2018 found USACE lacked approach for tracking deferred maintenance, limiting management ability
painPoints.source: GAO 2018 Inland Waterways Report & National Academies Review

painPoints.point: Climate resilience for Superfund sites - 945 sites (60% of NPL) in areas affected by flooding, storm surge, wildfires, or sea-level rise
painPoints.source: EPA Superfund Climate Resilience & USACE Climate Adaptation Screening

painPoints.point: Inadequate navigation funding - current budget does not provide adequate funding to keep all channels open to authorized levels
painPoints.source: Atlantic Intracoastal Waterway Association & USACE FY2025 Budget

painPoints.point: Hazardous waste infrastructure pressure - PFAS designation increasing site investigations, remediation capacity, and treatment technology needs
painPoints.source: ASCE Hazardous Waste Infrastructure Report Card

painPoints.point: Coastal flood risk management execution challenges - $2.55B BIL allocation requires complex storm risk management project delivery
painPoints.source: Bipartisan Infrastructure Law USACE Allocation & Resilient Norfolk Project

painPoints.point: Environmental justice requirements - 25% of BIL inland flood funds must benefit economically disadvantaged communities
painPoints.source: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act USACE Equity Requirements

strategicPriorities.priority: Bipartisan Infrastructure Law execution - $17.1B for water infrastructure including nearly 50 agreements and 100+ construction activities
strategicPriorities.source: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act CRS Report IN11723

strategicPriorities.priority: Flood risk management - coastal storm risk ($2.55B) and inland flood risk ($2.50B) infrastructure
strategicPriorities.source: BIL USACE Allocation & NWF Nature-based Funding Database

strategicPriorities.priority: Navigation infrastructure and dredging - 44% of FY2026 budget request ($2.99B) for harbor and waterway maintenance
strategicPriorities.source: USACE FY2026 Appropriations CRS Report IF13039

strategicPriorities.priority: PFAS contamination remediation at 586 military sites using DOD-funded demonstration projects
strategicPriorities.source: GAO-25-107401 & Waste Dive DOD PFAS Demo Projects
strategicPriorities.deadline: DOD regional screening levels guidance Q1 FY2025

strategicPriorities.priority: Small Business MATOC programs - $400M Savannah District, $99M Sacramento & Omaha Districts, $90M New England, $75M Dam/Levee Safety
Climate adaptation for Superfund remedies - incorporating climate resilience as core factor in cleanup design
Environmental restoration and remediation with equity focus - prioritizing economically disadvantaged communities
strategicPriorities.source: BIL USACE Equity Requirements & Flood Plain Management Services
strategicPriorities.funding: $45M Flood Plain Management, $51.4M Section 205 Flood Damage Protection

setAsidePreferences.smallBusiness: Very strong preference - $750M+ in active small business MATOCs, multiple districts with 100% small business set-asides
setAsidePreferences.WOSB: Active use in A-E and construction MATOCs
setAsidePreferences.HUBZone: Regular use for economically disadvantaged community projects
setAsidePreferences.SDVOSB: Strong preference - $99M dedicated SDVOSB MATOC Omaha District

typicalContractSizes.large: $50M - $400M (MATOC programs, major navigation projects, coastal resilience infrastructure)

prefers: Past performance with civil works or military construction
PFAS contamination remediation expertise and treatment technology

procurementCharacteristics.competitionLevel: Competitive for unrestricted, moderate for set-asides due to dedicated small business programs
evaluationFactors: Technical approach and civil works expertise
Past performance with USACE or similar water resource agencies
Small business participation and subcontracting plan

Equity and disadvantaged community benefits (for BIL projects)

25% of BIL inland flood funds ($625M) must benefit economically disadvantaged communities - equity requirements create targeting opportunities
